awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Geophysical characterization of a karst aquifer using dynamic recharge events
awd_abstract_narration:
Karst aquifers are important water resources, providing water for up to a quarter of the world?s population. These aquifers are complex hydrogeologic systems, where flow and transport predominantly occur through preferential flow paths or conduits that range in size from cm-scale openings to passages much larger than required for human access (caves). Despite their hydrologic importance, the location of karst conduits and characteristics of the larger aquifer are typically poorly constrained. To address these problems, we will monitor recharge-induced responses that arise as water flows into the subsurface in a karst aquifer in Florida using geophysical instrumentation to characterize the conduits, subsurface flow, and the larger karst system. The noninvasive remote sensing investigation will generate knowledge for direct societal benefit, including tools to improve the creation of karst hazards maps that highlight areas susceptible to sinkhole formation, the identification of preferential flow paths relevant to contaminant transport, and the development of a methodology to determine subsurface flow for water supply considerations. We will develop a temporary, interactive traveling exhibit in collaboration with the National Cave and Karst Research Institute that will frequent visitor centers near the field site in Florida and in New Mexico to increase public engagement and scientific literacy about karst hydrogeology and environmental seismology. The project will also contribute to the education of the next generation of the scientific workforce through the involvement of two graduate students at New Mexico Tech, an undergraduate student at the University of Florida, two undergraduate student interns through the IRIS undergraduate student intern program, and two early career scientists and a mid-career female scientist in an EPSCoR state. Finally, collected datasets will be incorporated into lecture material and homework sets of undergraduate and graduate courses at New Mexico Tech, which is a Hispanic-serving institution.
A previous pilot study demonstrated the generation of seismic signals during artificial recharge experiments and a natural recharge event in a karst aquifer. These and other geophysical signals are caused by processes during flow through karst aquifers and includes pressure pulses generated as recharge enters conduits with full pipe flow, pore pressure changes in fractures and the rock matrix, mass loading induced subsidence due to changes in water mass, and turbulent interaction of flow with the wall rocks. To capitalize on the information content provided by these signals, we will use simultaneous, large-scale observations of recharge events at two co-located geophysical sensor networks to characterize the conduit network, flow processes within this network, and material properties of the larger karst system. Seismometers, tiltmeters, and other instruments will be deployed at the Santa Fe River Sink-Rise system in Florida to observe karst recharge events over a two-year period. This field site has a well-constrained conduit network, and thus it permits verification of the interpreted geophysical signals that arise from hydrologic processes. This transformative project will not only enable delineation of the karst conduit network, but will do so while providing a regionally integrated analysis of the karst aquifer flow system based on deformation observations on the timescales between fractions of a second to months. As recharge activates new flow paths, geophysical monitoring enables extensive 3D characterization of the dynamics and evolution of flow during recharge-induced changes in the aquifer. Furthermore, the signals will help to determine the architecture in the subsurface between the conduits and the surface, advancing knowledge of critical zone environments, for example, by specifically determining soil and regolith thicknesses and depths to the soil-rock interface. The young field of environmental seismology encompasses studies of a range of Earth surface processes, and this project will use and expand the respective methods to transform the understanding of karst aquifers across the full frequency range of deformation and develop techniques in preparation for a future karst critical zone observatory.


This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Karst aquifers are complex hydrogeologic systems, where conduits facilitate much of the flow and transport through the aquifers. In many cases, there is little known about the structure of these aquifers, and much of our understanding relies on point measurements at springs, wells, or portions of caves that we can enter. Our research used geophysics as a way to monitor more broadly for processes relevant to the flow of water through these aquifers and to characterize unknown subsurface characteristics.

During a pilot study, we monitored seismic responses resulting from injection experiments. This involved pouring a large volume of water into a dry overflow spring so that the water could enter and flow through a subsurface conduit network. We also captured seismic responses that resulted from a large rainstorm that occurred during the brief study. Our analyses led us to conclude that the most likely explanation for the largest seismic signals recorded was that the energy resulted from the release of compressed air pockets, where air pockets in conduits became compressed as water levels rose during the recharge event and then the compressed air was released upon encountering a ventilation pathway. This suggests that seismic monitoring can be used to capture flow and recharge-induced dynamics in conduits and thus identify and delineate subsurface conduits.

We collected a three-year geophysical, hydrologic, and meteorological dataset involving an instrument network at the Santa Fe River Sink-Rise flow system in O’Leno and River Rise Preserve State Parks in north-central Florida. Our instrument network included 14 seismometers; four borehole and two platform tiltmeters; hydrologic sensors measuring water level, temperature, and electrical conductivity in four shallow wells, seven deeper wells, and seven surface water bodies; a barometric logger in the dry portion of a well; a weather station measuring temperature, atmospheric pressure, relative humidity, dew point, precipitation, wind speed, wind gust speed, and wind direction; and five motion cameras to document movement at the surface (animal and human activities). In addition, we also deployed 149 nodal seismometers for a one-month campaign at three locations within the parks.

The coupling of geophysics, hydrology, and meteorology datasets aided interpretations of collected data from the field, and our research characterized the unique seismic and tilt attributes and frequency content of a variety of environmental processes. This included natural processes at the surface (such as hurricanes and rain events), subsurface processes associated with flow through conduits, and anthropogenic activities. We also compared tilt and seismic responses to large magnitude earthquakes.

In addition, our research applied two interferometry methods for the processing of ambient seismic noise data to support the use of short-period seismic waves to investigate shallow subsurface structures. The first is the conventional amplitude-based cross-correlation and linear stacking method (TCC-Lin), and the second is a more recently introduced phase cross-correlation and time-frequency phase-weighted stacking method (PCC-PWS). We found that the PCC-PWS method is superior for complex shallow subsurface structures because it has greater waveform sensitivity and more efficiency for short-period wave extraction.

Ambient seismic noise tomography enables the characterization of karst aquifer structure and monitoring for groundwater levels. Variable porosity and permeability control seismic velocities, and this allowed us to identify hydrogeological units as well as the degree of karstification. Our ambient noise analyses also considered spatiotemporal variations in seismic surface wave speed (dv/v), and we found that water table fluctuations are correlated with dv/v changes. Our study improves the characterization of hydrogeological properties and monitoring of water resources, which aids groundwater management and modeling.

We also modeled ground deformation that results from karst conduit pressurization and compared these results to aid interpretation of our field tiltmeter data. Models considered recharge events that induce pore pressure, vertical displacement, and tilt changes in Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic confined and unconfined aquifer cases. We found that the hydraulic diffusivity of the aquifer controls the poroelastic signal in the aquifer and the impact of mechanical and coupling parameters on the magnitude of the deformational response. Our results suggest that tilt monitoring can be used to infer conduit location and conduit size.

Broader impacts of our project included the training and professional development of six PhD students, two postdoctoral research associates, and eighteen undergraduate students at three academic institutions. We also developed an interactive museum exhibit that involves monitoring seismic signals during flow through caves in a physical karst aquifer model. The museum exhibit is currently on display in the museum of the Meyer Science Center at Wheaton College, and a video of the museum exhibit may be seen on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wuMYqFjxg1Q).
